lines.text: Enter, from the cave, BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, ARVIRAGUS, and IMOGEN

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: [To IMOGEN]  You are not well: remain here in the cave Well come to you after hunting.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: [To IMOGEN]Brother, stay here Are we not brothers

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: So man and man should be But clay and clay differs in dignity, Whose dust is both alike. I am very sick.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Go you to hunting Ill abide with him.

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: So sick I am not, yet I am not well But not so citizen a wanton as To seem to die ere sick: so please you, leave me Stick to your journal course: the breach of custom Is breach of all. I am ill, but your being by me Cannot amend me society is no comfort To one not sociable: I am not very sick, Since I can reason of it. Pray you, trust me here: Ill rob none but myself and let me die, Stealing so poorly.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: I love thee I have spoke it How much the quantity, the weight as much, As I do love my father.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: What! how! how!

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: If it be sin to say so, I yoke me In my good brothers fault: I know not why I love this youth and I have heard you say, Loves reasons without reason: the bier at door, And a demand who ist shall die, Id say My father, not this youth.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: [Aside]O noble strain! O worthiness of nature! breed of greatness! Cowards father cowards and base things sire base: Nature hath meal and bran, contempt and grace. Im not their father yet who this should be, Doth miracle itself, loved before me. Tis the ninth hour o the morn.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Brother, farewell.

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: I wish ye sport.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: You health. So please you, sir.

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: [Aside]  These are kind creatures. Gods, what lies I have heard! Our courtiers say alls savage but at court: Experience, O, thou disprovest report! The imperious seas breed monsters, for the dish Poor tributary rivers as sweet fish. I am sick still heartsick. Pisanio, Ill now taste of thy drug.
Swallows some

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: I could not stir him: He said he was gentle, but unfortunate Dishonestly afflicted, but yet honest.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Thus did he answer me: yet said, hereafter I might know more.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: To the field, to the field! Well leave you for this time: go in and rest.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Well not be long away.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: Pray, be not sick, For you must be our housewife.

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: Well or ill, I am bound to you.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: And shalt be ever. This youth, hower distressd, appears he hath had Good ancestors.
Exit IMOGEN, to the cave

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: How angellike he sings!

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: But his neat cookery! he cut our roots In characters, And sauced our broths, as Juno had been sick And he her dieter.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Nobly he yokes A smiling with a sigh, as if the sigh Was that it was, for not being such a smile The smile mocking the sigh, that it would fly From so divine a temple, to commix With winds that sailors rail at.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: I do note That grief and patience, rooted in him both, Mingle their spurs together.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Grow, patience! And let the stinking elder, grief, untwine His perishing root with the increasing vine!

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: It is great morning. Come, away! Whos there
Enter CLOTEN

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: I cannot find those runagates that villain Hath mockd me. I am faint.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: Those runagates! Means he not us I partly know him: tis Cloten, the son o the queen. I fear some ambush. I saw him not these many years, and yet I know tis he. We are held as outlaws: hence!

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: He is but one: you and my brother search What companies are near: pray you, away Let me alone with him.
Exeunt BELARIUS and ARVIRAGUS

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Soft! What are you That fly me thus some villain mountaineers I have heard of such. What slave art thou

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: A thing More slavish did I neer than answering A slave without a knock.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Thou art a robber, A lawbreaker, a villain: yield thee, thief.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: To who to thee What art thou Have not I An arm as big as thine a heart as big Thy words, I grant, are bigger, for I wear not My dagger in my mouth. Say what thou art, Why I should yield to thee

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Thou villain base, Knowst me not by my clothes

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: No, nor thy tailor, rascal, Who is thy grandfather: he made those clothes, Which, as it seems, make thee.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Thou precious varlet, My tailor made them not.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Hence, then, and thank The man that gave them thee. Thou art some fool I am loath to beat thee.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Thou injurious thief, Hear but my name, and tremble.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Whats thy name

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Cloten, thou villain.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Cloten, thou double villain, be thy name, I cannot tremble at it: were it Toad, or Adder, Spider, Twould move me sooner.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: To thy further fear, Nay, to thy mere confusion, thou shalt know I am son to the queen.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: I am sorry for t not seeming So worthy as thy birth.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Art not afeard

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Those that I reverence those I fear, the wise: At fools I laugh, not fear them.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Die the death: When I have slain thee with my proper hand, Ill follow those that even now fled hence, And on the gates of Ludstown set your heads: Yield, rustic mountaineer.
Exeunt, fighting
Reenter BELARIUS and ARVIRAGUS

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: No companies abroad

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: None in the world: you did mistake him, sure.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: I cannot tell: long is it since I saw him, But time hath nothing blurrd those lines of favour Which then he wore the snatches in his voice, And burst of speaking, were as his: I am absolute Twas very Cloten.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: In this place we left them: I wish my brother make good time with him, You say he is so fell.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: Being scarce made up, I mean, to man, he had not apprehension Of roaring terrors for the effect of judgment Is oft the cause of fear. But, see, thy brother.
Reenter GUIDERIUS, with CLOTENS head

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: This Cloten was a fool, an empty purse There was no money int: not Hercules Could have knockd out his brains, for he had none: Yet I not doing this, the fool had borne My head as I do his.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: What hast thou done

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: I am perfect what: cut off one Clotens head, Son to the queen, after his own report Who calld me traitor, mountaineer, and swore With his own single hand held take us in Displace our heads wherethank the gods!they grow, And set them on Ludstown.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: We are all undone.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Why, worthy father, what have we to lose, But that he swore to take, our lives The law Protects not us: then why should we be tender To let an arrogant piece of flesh threat us, Play judge and executioner all himself, For we do fear the law What company Discover you abroad

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: No single soul Can we set eye on but in all safe reason He must have some attendants. Though his humour Was nothing but mutation, ay, and that From one bad thing to worse not frenzy, not Absolute madness could so far have raved To bring him here alone although perhaps It may be heard at court that such as we Cave here, hunt here, are outlaws, and in time May make some stronger head the which he hearing As it is like himmight break out, and swear Held fetch us in yet ist not probable To come alone, either he so undertaking, Or they so suffering: then on good ground we fear, If we do fear this body hath a tail More perilous than the head.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Let ordinance Come as the gods foresay it: howsoeer, My brother hath done well.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: I had no mind To hunt this day: the boy Fideles sickness Did make my way long forth.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: With his own sword, Which he did wave against my throat, I have taen His head from him: Ill throwt into the creek Behind our rock and let it to the sea, And tell the fishes hes the queens son, Cloten: Thats all I reck.
Exit

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: I fear twill be revenged: Would, Polydote, thou hadst not donet! though valour Becomes thee well enough.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Would I had donet So the revenge alone pursued me! Polydore, I love thee brotherly, but envy much Thou hast robbd me of this deed: I would revenges, That possible strength might meet, would seek us through And put us to our answer.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: Well, tis done: Well hunt no more today, nor seek for danger Where theres no profit. I prithee, to our rock You and Fidele play the cooks: Ill stay Till hasty Polydote return, and bring him To dinner presently.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Poor sick Fidele! Ill weringly to him: to gain his colour Ild let a parish of such Clotens blood, And praise myself for charity.
Exit

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: O thou goddess, Thou divine Nature, how thyself thou blazonst In these two princely boys! They are as gentle As zephyrs blowing below the violet, Not wagging his sweet head and yet as rough, Their royal blood enchafed, as the rudest wind, That by the top doth take the mountain pine, And make him stoop to the vale. Tis wonder That an invisible instinct should frame them To royalty unlearnd, honour untaught, Civility not seen from other, valour That wildly grows in them, but yields a crop As if it had been sowd. Yet still its strange What Clotens being here to us portends, Or what his death will bring us.
Reenter GUIDERIUS

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Wheres my brother I have sent Clotens clotpoll down the stream, In embassy to his mother: his bodys hostage For his return.
Solemn music

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: My ingenious instrument! Hark, Polydore, it sounds! But what occasion Hath Cadwal now to give it motion Hark!

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Is he at home

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: He went hence even now.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: What does he mean since death of my dearst mother it did not speak before. All solemn things Should answer solemn accidents. The matter Triumphs for nothing and lamenting toys Is jollity for apes and grief for boys. Is Cadwal mad

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: Look, here he comes, And brings the dire occasion in his arms Of what we blame him for.
Reenter ARVIRAGUS, with IMOGEN, as dead, bearing her in his arms

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: The bird is dead That we have made so much on. I had rather Have skippd from sixteen years of age to sixty, To have turnd my leapingtime into a crutch, Than have seen this.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: O sweetest, fairest lily! My brother wears thee not the one half so well As when thou grewst thyself.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: O melancholy! Who ever yet could sound thy bottom find The ooze, to show what coast thy sluggish crare Might easiliest harbour in Thou blessed thing! Jove knows what man thou mightst have made but I, Thou diedst, a most rare boy, of melancholy. How found you him

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Stark, as you see: Thus smiling, as some fly hid tickled slumber, Not as deaths dart, being laughd at his right cheek Reposing on a cushion.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Where

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: O the floor His arms thus leagued: I thought he slept, and put My clouted brogues from off my feet, whose rudeness Answerd my steps too loud.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Why, he but sleeps: If he be gone, hell make his grave a bed With female fairies will his tomb be haunted, And worms will not come to thee.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: With fairest flowers Whilst summer lasts and I live here, Fidele, Ill sweeten thy sad grave: thou shalt not lack The flower thats like thy face, pale primrose, nor The azured harebell, like thy veins, no, nor The leaf of eglantine, whom not to slander, Outsweetend not thy breath: the ruddock would, With charitable bill,O bill, soreshaming Those richleft heirs that let their fathers lie Without a monument!bring thee all this Yea, and furrd moss besides, when flowers are none, To winterground thy corse.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Prithee, have done And do not play in wenchlike words with that Which is so serious. Let us bury him, And not protract with admiration what Is now due debt. To the grave!

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Say, where shalls lay him

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: By good Euriphile, our mother.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Bet so: And let us, Polydore, though now our voices Have got the mannish crack, sing him to the ground, As once our mother use like note and words, Save that Euriphile must be Fidele.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Cadwal, I cannot sing: Ill weep, and word it with thee For notes of sorrow out of tune are worse Than priests and fanes that lie.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Well speak it, then.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: Great griefs, I see, medicine the less for Cloten Is quite forgot. He was a queens son, boys And though he came our enemy, remember He was paid for that: though mean and mighty, rotting Together, have one dust, yet reverence, That angel of the world, doth make distinction Of place tween high and low. Our foe was princely And though you took his life, as being our foe, Yet bury him as a prince.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Pray You, fetch him hither. Thersites body is as good as Ajax, When neither are alive.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: If youll go fetch him, Well say our song the whilst. Brother, begin.
Exit BELARIUS

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Nay, Cadwal, we must lay his head to the east My father hath a reason fort.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Tis true.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Come on then, and remove him.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: So. Begin.
SONG

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Fear no more the heat o the sun, Nor the furious winters rages Thou thy worldly task hast done, Home art gone, and taen thy wages: Golden lads and girls all must, As chimneysweepers, come to dust.

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Fear no more the frown o the great Thou art past the tyrants stroke Care no more to clothe and eat To thee the reed is as the oak: The sceptre, learning, physic, must All follow this, and come to dust.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Fear no more the lightning flash,

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Nor the alldreaded thunderstone

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Fear not slander, censure rash

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Thou hast finishd joy and moan: All lovers young, all lovers must Consign to thee, and come to dust.

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: No exorciser harm thee!

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Nor no witchcraft charm thee!

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: Ghost unlaid forbear thee!

lines.speaker: arviragus
lines.text: Nothing ill come near thee! Quiet consummation have And renowned be thy grave!
Reenter BELARIUS, with the body of CLOTEN

lines.speaker: guiderius
lines.text: We have done our obsequies: come, lay him down.

lines.speaker: belarius
lines.text: Heres a few flowers but bout midnight, more: The herbs that have on them cold dew o the night Are strewings fittst for graves. Upon their faces. You were as flowers, now witherd: even so These herblets shall, which we upon you strew. Come on, away: apart upon our knees. The ground that gave them first has them again: Their pleasures here are past, so is their pain.
Exeunt BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: [Awaking]  Yes, sir, to MilfordHaven which is the way I thank you.By yond bushPray, how far thither Ods pittikins! can it be six mile yet I have gone all night. Faith, Ill lie down and sleep. But, soft! no bedfellow!O god s and goddesses! These flowers are like the pleasures of the world This bloody man, the care ont. I hope I dream For so I thought I was a cavekeeper, And cook to honest creatures: but tis not so Twas but a bolt of nothing, shot at nothing, Which the brain makes of fumes: our very eyes Are sometimes like our judgments, blind. Good faith, I tremble stiff with fear: but if there be Yet left in heaven as small a drop of pity As a wrens eye, feard gods, a part of it! The dreams here still: even when I wake, it is Without me, as within me not imagined, felt. A headless man! The garments of Posthumus! I know the shape ofs leg: this is his hand His foot Mercurial his Martial thigh The brawns of Hercules: but his Jovial face Murder in heavenHow!Tis gone. Pisanio, All curses madded Hecuba gave the Greeks, And mine to boot, be darted on thee! Thou, Conspired with that irregulous devil, Cloten, Hast here cut off my lord. To write and read Be henceforth treacherous! Damnd Pisanio Hath with his forged letters,damnd Pisanio From this most bravest vessel of the world Struck the maintop! O Posthumus! alas, Where is thy head wheres that Ay me! wheres that Pisanio might have killd thee at the heart, And left this head on. How should this be Pisanio Tis he and Cloten: malice and lucre in them Have laid this woe here. O, tis pregnant, pregnant! The drug he gave me, which he said was precious And cordial to me, have I not found it Murderous to the senses That confirms it home: This is Pisanios deed, and Clotens: O! Give colour to my pale cheek with thy blood, That we the horrider may seem to those Which chance to find us: O, my lord, my lord!
Seeing the body of CLOTEN
Falls on the body
Enter LUCIUS, a Captain and other Officers, and a Soothsayer

lines.speaker: captain
lines.text: To them the legions garrisond in Gailia, After your will, have crossd the sea, attending You here at MilfordHaven with your ships: They are in readiness.

lines.speaker: caius lucius
lines.text: But what from Rome

lines.speaker: captain
lines.text: The senate hath stirrd up the confiners And gentlemen of Italy, most willing spirits, That promise noble service: and they come Under the conduct of bold Iachimo, Syennas brother.

lines.speaker: caius lucius
lines.text: When expect you them

lines.speaker: captain
lines.text: With the next benefit o the wind.

lines.speaker: caius lucius
lines.text: This forwardness Makes our hopes fair. Command our present numbers Be musterd bid the captains look tot. Now, sir, What have you dreamd of late of this wars purpose

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: Last night the very gods showd me a vision I fast and prayd for their intelligencethus: I saw Joves bird, the Roman eagle, wingd From the spongy south to this part of the west, There vanishd in the sunbeams: which portends Unless my sins abuse my divination Success to the Roman host.

lines.speaker: caius lucius
lines.text: Dream often so, And never false. Soft, ho! what trunk is here Without his top The ruin speaks that sometime It was a worthy building. How! a page! Or dead, or sleeping on him But dead rather For nature doth abhor to make his bed With the defunct, or sleep upon the dead. Lets see the boys face.

lines.speaker: captain
lines.text: Hes alive, my lord.

lines.speaker: caius lucius
lines.text: Hell then instruct us of this body. Young one, Inform us of thy fortunes, for it seems They crave to be demanded. Who is this Thou makest thy bloody pillow Or who was he That, otherwise than noble nature did, Hath alterd that good picture Whats thy interest In this sad wreck How came it Who is it What art thou

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: I am nothing: or if not, Nothing to be were better. This was my master, A very valiant Briton and a good, That here by mountaineers lies slain. Alas! There is no more such masters: I may wander From east to occident, cry out for service, Try many, all good, serve truly, never Find such another master.

lines.speaker: caius lucius
lines.text: Lack, good youth! Thou movest no less with thy complaining than Thy master in bleeding: say his name, good friend.

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: Richard du Champ. If I do lie and do No harm by it, though the gods hear, I hope Theyll pardon it.Say you, sir
Aside

lines.speaker: caius lucius
lines.text: Thy name

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: Fidele, sir.

lines.speaker: caius lucius
lines.text: Thou dost approve thyself the very same: Thy name well fits thy faith, thy faith thy name. Wilt take thy chance with me I will not say Thou shalt be so well masterd, but, be sure, No less beloved. The Roman emperors letters, Sent by a consul to me, should not sooner Than thine own worth prefer thee: go with me.

lines.speaker: imogen
lines.text: Ill follow, sir. But first, ant please the gods, Ill hide my master from the flies, as deep As these poor pickaxes can dig and when With wild woodleaves and weeds I ha strewd his grave, And on it said a century of prayers, Such as I can, twice oer, Ill weep and sigh And leaving so his service, follow you, So please you entertain me.

lines.speaker: caius lucius
lines.text: Ay, good youth! And rather father thee than master thee. My friends, The boy hath taught us manly duties: let us Find out the prettiest daisied plot we can, And make him with our pikes and partisans A grave: come, arm him. Boy, he is preferrd By thee to us, and he shall be interrd As soldiers can. Be cheerful wipe thine eyes Some falls are means the happier to arise.
Exeunt
